stem: The patient is experiencing autonomic dysreflexia. Based on the assessment findings in the EHR, indicate whether each intervention is indicated, contraindicated, or neutral at this time.

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct: Elevating the head of the bed helps to lower blood pressure by promoting venous pooling in the lower extremities. Assessing for bowel impaction is crucial as it is a common trigger for autonomic dysreflexia. Administering antihypertensive medication (hydralazine) as prescribed is essential to lower the dangerously high blood pressure. Removing constrictive clothing can help improve circulation and reduce external pressure. Checking for bladder distension, even with a patent catheter, is important as the catheter may not be draining effectively due to kinks, sediment, or bladder spasms.

mnemonic.title: SIT UP
mnemonic.expansion: S: Sit the patient up (elevate HOB). I: Investigate the cause (bladder, bowel, skin). T: Treat the blood pressure (antihypertensives). U: Undo constrictive clothing. P: Prevent further episodes (patient education).

rationale.incorrect: Administering a beta-blocker is contraindicated as it can worsen bradycardia, which is already present due to the autonomic dysreflexia. Lowering the head of the bed would increase blood pressure further, exacerbating the hypertensive crisis. Placing the patient in Trendelenburg position would significantly increase blood pressure and is absolutely contraindicated. Encouraging deep breathing exercises is not the priority in this acute situation as it does not directly address the hypertension. Massaging the legs is contraindicated as it could potentially dislodge a clot and increase venous return, further raising blood pressure.

questionTrap.trap: The question focuses on immediate interventions. Many students might fixate on bowel impaction as *the* cause and miss the need for immediate blood pressure management.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize interventions based on immediacy. Lowering blood pressure is paramount. Then, focus on identifying and addressing the trigger.

clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention.
Always prioritize assessing and addressing the underlying cause of autonomic dysreflexia.
Elevate the head of the bed as the FIRST intervention to reduce BP.

itemContext.sbar: S: This is John Smith, a 52-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury, admitted three days ago. I'm calling because he's exhibiting signs of autonomic dysreflexia. B: Patient had a T6 SCI two years ago due to a motor vehicle accident. He has chronic neurogenic bowel and bladder. He typically self-catheterizes every four hours. A: At 07:00, his BP was 120/80 mmHg, HR 72 bpm. At 09:00, his BP is 210/110 mmHg, HR 50 bpm. He reports a pounding headache, blurred vision, and nasal congestion. Skin is flushed above the level of injury and pale below. I checked his catheter, and it is patent. His last bowel movement was yesterday. Assess: The patient is experiencing autonomic dysreflexia. R: I recommend an immediate assessment for potential triggers, administration of PRN hydralazine as prescribed, and continued monitoring of vital signs.
